original_data.question: A 68-year-old man presents with difficulty breathing for the last 3 hours. Upon asking about other symptoms, he mentions that he had a cough for the last 4 months which he attributes to his smoking. He says he had frequent nasal stuffiness and headaches over the last 3 months, for which he takes over-the-counter cold medications and analgesics. Over the last 2 months, he often felt that his face was mildly swollen, especially in the morning hours, but he did not consider it to be anything serious. No significant past medical history. He reports a 20-pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F), pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 108/78 mm Hg, and the respiratory rate is 24/min. On physical examination, auscultation of the chest reveals rhonchi and crepitus over the right lung. The remainder of the exam is unremarkable. A chest radiograph reveals a mass in the middle lobe of the right lung. Which of the following clinical signs would most likely be present in this patient?

options.D: Sensory loss over the ulnar aspect of right forearm and right hand

model_response:
The patient's symptoms are suggestive of lung cancer. The presence of clubbing and pedal edema suggest lung cancer with paraneoplastic syndrome. The most common paraneoplastic syndromes associated with lung cancer are hypercalcemia, erythrocytosis, and hepatic dysfunction. Clubbing is present in up to 20% of patients with lung cancer. Paraneoplastic syndromes are classified as metabolic, neuromuscular, connective tissue, dermatologic, and vascular. The vascular paraneoplastic syndromes are hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy (clubbing and peripheral edema), and the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH). Hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy is more common in adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma. SIADH is more common in small cell carcinoma.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Difficult or labored breathing.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Any of the properties, roles, or associations, that define a concept.
Willful or deliberate act of inhaling and exhaling SMOKE from burning substances or agents held by hand.
Coming at short intervals or in great quantities.
The blockage of the nasal passage due to mucosal edema. It is usually the result of a viral infection or an allergic reaction.
The symptom of PAIN in the cranial region. It may be an isolated benign occurrence or manifestation of a wide variety of HEADACHE DISORDERS.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Compounds capable of relieving pain without the loss of CONSCIOUSNESS.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
The anterior portion of the head that includes the skin, muscles, and structures of the forehead, eyes, nose, mouth, cheeks, and jaw.
Enlargement; expansion in size; sign of inflammation
The time period between dawn and noon.

A term applied to differences, correlations, cause-and-effect relationships, etc., to indicate that they are noticeable, probably too closely correlated to be attributed to chance and therefore indicating a systematic relation: substantial, fairly large; also having consequence or import, important in effect or meaning. In statistics significant ordinarily indicates a probability of not less than 95 percent, while highly significant indicates a probability of not less than 99 percent.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
The history of when and what an individual smoke(s) or smoked.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Act of listening for sounds within the body.
Air trapped in the subcutaneous space. It can be palpated or heard as a crackling or grating sensation under the skin.
The 3-lobed lung located on the right side of the body.
An appraisal or evaluation of a patient's condition by a clinician that is based on a physical exam, medical history, and the patient's account of symptoms.
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes.
The smallest lobe of the right lung, situated above the oblique fissure and below the horizontal fissure.
The 3-lobed lung located on the right side of the body.
Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation. The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
